author: pixel_pavel
content:
Really excited about 1559 and Iâ€™m trying to understand the deflationary aspects better. What is the expected average basefee that will be needed to burn off the equivalent of the 2 Eth block reward? My (probably incorrect) math is saying 133 Gwei.

```
2 Eth block reward = 2B Gwei
2B Gwei / 15M gas block (sustained average block size) = 133
```

Does that sound right?

author: sky.cactus
content: Sounds right to me.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Don't forget that sometimes uncles also get included, so the actual deflationary gas fee is higher, and is also stochastic.

author: yuga.eth
content:
This is awesome, thank you! Couple q's:
1. Is there a block explorer for Baikal?
2. If not, any chance you could send over an example of a 1559 TX? Specifically interested in both its hex representation, as well as its JSON representation. (We're implementing 1559 signing and want to write tests to make sure we're doing it right.)

author: lightclient
content: block explorer: http://18.224.51.102:3000

author: yuga.eth
content: Thank you! Does this explorer surface EIP-2718/1559-related info, like transaction type, maxPriorityFee, etc.?

author: lightclient
content: Iâ€™m not sure

author: matkt0
content: for now in this version we only have the baseFee of each block

author: yuga.eth
content: OK. It would be really useful to be able to see TX-related info (feature request) ðŸ™‚

author: holgerd77
content: <@!829793517378863164> you can find some test EIP-1559 tx JSON files as well as code parts in our EthereumJS tx library test folder, e.g. https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-monorepo/blob/master/packages/tx/test/eip1559.spec.ts (see e.g. the "toJSON()" test) or https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-monorepo/blob/master/packages/tx/test/json/eip1559.json or https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-monorepo/blob/master/packages/tx/test/json/eip1559txs.json , maybe this helps and you can use it.

author: timbeiko
content:
The JSON RPC spec has been merged, you can find it here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-specs/blob/master/json-rpc/spec.json

If you want a nicer output, you can copy/paste the raw JSON here: https://playground.open-rpc.org/

author: timbeiko
content: <@!425269142615097345> what exactly do those "BaseFee development" numbers represent?

author: pixel_pavel
content: Where would uncles factor into the equation? Would that be higher total issuance than the 2 ETH?

author: timbeiko
content: For example, this block has an extra 1.75 ETH uncle reward: https://etherscan.io/block/12465985

author: pixel_pavel
content: Thx, so the basefee would need to be > 133 Gwei to account for offsetting the uncles, and even higher than that to become deflationary. That seems like an expensive basefee to sustain, or am I missing something?

author: timbeiko
content: <@!616758295906091023> the goal of EIP-1559 isn't to make ETH deflationary, so, your math is fine, but we don't need to "sustain" that base fee. The purpose of the base fee is just to act as an in-protocol market price indicator for gas.

author: holgerd77
content: <@!552133098075193354> ah, that's just "how the baseFee is developing", so stating the block numbers and the respective baseFee change (just to get some feeling how quick this drops)

author: pixel_pavel
content: Good point. A lot of the discussions and coverage of EIP-1559 have focused on the deflationary aspect, which sounds like that *could* happen, eg when basefees are very high, or issuance is reduced. But it won't be the norm.

author: jochembrouwer
content: This also depends on the gas limit of the blocks, if we double it, ETH would get deflationary with half the mentioned gas price ðŸ™‚

author: timbeiko
content: Also worth noting that most analyzes that predict deflationary ETH assume the post-merge inflation rate (e.g. only the beacon chain issuance, not PoW issuance), which is much lower.
